{{For|complete team history|History of the Chicago Bears}} {{For|complete list of team awards|List of Chicago Bears award winners}} [[Image:SoliderFieldAug2004.jpg|thumb|right|Soldier Field, current home of the Chicago Bears]] The [[Chicago Bears]] [[Professional sports league organization|franchise]] was originally founded as the [[Decatur, Illinois|Decatur]] Staleys, a charter member of the [[American Professional Football Association]] (APFA). The team moved to [[Chicago, Illinois]] in 1921 and changed its name to the Bears in 1922, the same year the APFA changed its name to the [[National Football League]] (NFL).{{cite web |url=http://www.bearshistory.com/seasons/index.aspx |title=Chicago Bears Seasons By Era |accessdate=2008-08-15 |last=Taylor |first=Roy |coauthors= |year=2005 |work= |publisher=bearshistory.com}}{{cite web |url=http://www.nfl.com/history/chronology/1921-1930 |title=NFL History By Decade |accessdate=2008-08-15 |last= |first= |coauthors= |date= |work= |publisher=nfl.com/history}} This list documents the franchise's completed seasons from 1920 to present, including postseason records and results from postseason games.'''Note:''' The Finish, Wins, Losses, and Ties columns list only regular season game results and exclude any postseason play records. Regular and postseason records are combined only at the bottom of the list. The Chicago Bears have played over one thousand games in their history, which includes eight [[NFL Championships]] victories and one [[Super Bowl]] win. The Bears' nine championships are the second most by any team in history. The franchise has captured eighteen NFL divisional titles and four NFL conference championships. The Bears have also recorded more regular season and overall victories than any other NFL franchise.{{cite web |url=http://www.pro-football-reference.com/teams/chi/ |title=Chicago Bears Franchise Encyclopedia |accessdate=2008-08-15 |last= |first= |coauthors= |date= |work= |publisher=Sports Reference LLC}}{{cite web |url=http://www.pro-football-reference.com/teams/gnb/ |title=Green Bay Packers Franchise Encyclopedia |accessdate=2008-08-15 |last= |first= |coauthors= |date= |work= |publisher=Sports Reference LLC}}{{cite web |url=http://www.profootballhof.com/history/stats/win-loss_records.jsp|title=All-Time Win-Loss Records By Team |accessdate=2008-08-15 |last= |first= |coauthors= |year=2008 |work= |publisher=Pro Football Hall of Fame}} The franchise has experienced three major periods of continued success in their history. The first period of success came from {{nfly|1932}} to {{nfly|1946}} when the Bears played in nine NFL Championship Games, winning six of them. This period saw the Bears participate in the first ever [[NFL Playoff Game, 1932|National Football League playoff game]], the first ever official [[NFL Championship Game, 1933|NFL Championship Game]], and become the American football [[dynasty (sports)|sports dynasty]] of the 1940s. The Bears played in four straight NFL Championship Games between {{nfly|1940}} and {{nfly|1944}}, winning three of them, including an [[NFL records (team)|NFL record]] 73–0 victory over the [[Washington Redskins]] in [[NFL Championship Game, 1940|1940]].{{cite web |url=http://www.bearshistory.com/seasons/1930schicagobears.aspx|title=The 1930's Bears, First Dynasty |accessdate=2008-08-15 |last=Taylor |first=Roy |coauthors= |year=2004 |work= |publisher=bearshistory.com}}{{cite web |url=http://www.bearshistory.com/seasons/1940schicagobears.aspx|title=1940's Chicago Bears, Another Dynasty |accessdate=2008-08-15 |last=Taylor |first=Roy |coauthors= |year=2004 |work= |publisher=bearshistory.com}} The second period of success was between {{nfly|1984}} and {{nfly|1991}} when the Bears captured six [[NFC Central|NFC Central Division]] titles in eight years and won [[Super Bowl XX]].{{cite web |url=http://www.chicagobears.com/tradition/history_80s.asp|title=Highlights from the 1980s |accessdate=2008-08-15 |last= |first= |coauthors= |year=2008 |work= |publisher=chicagobears.com}}{{cite web |url=http://www.chicagobears.com/tradition/history_90s.asp|title=Highlights from the 1990s |accessdate=2008-08-15 |last= |first= |coauthors= |year=2008 |work= |publisher=chicagobears.com}} A brief period of success stretched from {{nfly|2005}} to [[2007 NFL season|2007]] when the franchise captured two straight [[NFC North]] titles and a [[NFC Championship]] title, which earned them a berth in [[Super Bowl XLI]], a game that the club lost to the [[Indianapolis Colts]].{{cite web |url=http://www.pro-football-reference.com/teams/chi/#playoffs|title=Playoff Game Log |accessdate=2008-08-15 |last= |first= |coauthors= |year=2008 |work= |publisher=pro-football-reference.com}} The Bears have experienced failure in their history. The franchise finished in last place within its division five times in the 1970s.{{cite web |url=http://www.chicagobears.com/tradition/history_70s.asp|title=Highlights from the 1970s |accessdate=2008-08-15 |last= |first= |coauthors= |year=2008 |work= |publisher=chicagobears.com}} In 1970, the team moved from [[Wrigley Field]] to [[Soldier Field]] to play its home games. In the mid- to late 1990s and early 2000s, the club posted six seasons with 10 or more losses. By chance, these two decades—the 1970s and 1990s—are the only decades in the Bears history that the franchise has not won or played for an NFL Championship or Super Bowl. In the {{nfly|1969}} season, the franchise posted their worst regular season record with a 1–13 showing.{{cite web |url=http://www.pro-football-reference.com/teams/chi/#playoffs|title=Team Records, Clubs played schedules that included games against nonleague opponents. *{{note label|Note2|b|b}}The NFL did not hold playoff games until 1932. The team that finished with the best regular season record was named the league champions. *{{note label|Note3|c|c}}The result of the [[1932 NFL Playoff Game]] to determine the NFL champion between the Bears and the [[Portsmouth Spartans]]. The game counted in the standings and broke the tie. *{{note label|Note4|d|d}}The score of the playoff game is in parenthesis with the winning score first no matter the outcome for the Bears. *{{note label|Note5|e|e}}The Bears were denied perfect seasons on two accounts. The first one was in the [[1934 Chicago Bears season|1934]] when the 13-0 club lost to the [[New York Giants]] in the Championship game. The second occurrence happened in [[1942 Chicago Bears season|1942]] when the 11-0 club was denied perfection and a "three-peat" by the [[Washington Redskins]]. *{{note label|Note6|f|f}}The Bears victory of the Redskins in the [[NFL Championship Game, 1940|1940 NFL Championship]] is an [[NFL_playoff_records_(team)|NFL record]] for greatest margin of victory and most points scored in a game. *{{note label|Note8|h|h}}The Bears tied with the Rams for 1st place at the end of the season, but they lost the One-Game playoff tiebreaker and therefore did not win a Conference Championship. *{{note label|Note9|i|i}}The [[1967 NFL season]] marks the first season in the league's history where the league was divided into two conferences which were subdivided into two divisions. Up to 1967, the league was either divided into two divisions, two conferences, or neither. *{{note label|Note10|j|j}}As a result of the [[AFL-NFL Merger]], the league was broken into two conferences, with the AFL teams moving into the American Football Conference. *{{note label|Note11|k|k}}As of the [[2010 NFL season]], this season marks the last tie game the Bears played. It was a game at [[Soldier Field]] on September 24, 1972 against the [[Los Angeles Rams]]. The game ended at 13–13. *{{note label|Note12|l|l}}The [[1982 NFL season|1982 season]] was a strike-shortened season so the league was divided up into two conferences instead of its normal divisional alignment. *{{note label|Note13|m|m}}This was the franchise's first [[Super Bowl]] victory and their ninth league championship. *{{note label|Note14|n|n}}The strike of [[1987 NFL season|1987]] reduced the regular season schedule from sixteen to fifteen games. *{{note label|Note15|o|o}}The Divisional Playoff game against the Eagles was known as the [[Fog Bowl (American football)|Fog Bowl]] due to the heavy fog that covered the field for most of the game. *{{note label|Note16|p|p}}As of the [[2010 NFL season]], this is the second postseason meeting of the Bears and [[Green Bay Packers]] in their [[Bears-Packers rivalry|long standing rivalry]]. *{{note label|Note17|q|q}}Records as of [[2010 NFL season|January 23, 2011]]. ==References== ;General * {{cite web | title = NFL Football History | work = CBS Sportsline | url = http://www.sportsline.com/nfl/history | accessdate = January 2, 2007 }} * {{cite web | title = Chicago Bears History | work = Chicago Bears History Website | url = http://www.bearshistory.com | accessdate = April 30, 2006 }} * {{cite web | title = Chicago Bears.com -
